FromThePage Title: [William Holt case testimonies]: Department of the Interior, Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Chelsea, I. T., June 20, 1901
FromThePage Description: William Holt, a formerly enslaved African American, testifies for enrollment as a Cherokee Freedman by answering questions about where he has resided. He claims that he has lived in Vinita in the Cherokee Nation "off and on" throughout his life, and that his father is Tecumseh Holt. He does not appear on tribal rolls of 1880 and 1896, or on the Kern-Clifton roll or Wallace roll. The Commissioner's decides to accept Holt's application on a doubtful card", since he did not appear to be included on any tribal roll and could not provide satisfactory "proof as to his residence."

FromThePage Title: Decision: in the matter of the application of George Bell et al. for enrollment as Cherokee Freedmen, consolidating the applications of George Bell, Cherokee Freedmen D 706 [and] July Bell, Cherokee Freedman D 1021.
FromThePage Description: Official decision of the Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes to reject the application of George and July Bell. They were enslaved by a Cherokee man by the name of L.B. Bell and were taken south after the Civil War began. However, the Bells did not return to the Cherokee Nation until May 1867, after the timeframe specified in the Treaty of 1866 and were not on the 1880 authenticated roll of the Cherokee Nation. It was decided to deny this case under provisions of the Curtis Act, approved by Congress on June 28, 1898.

FromThePage Title: [Jesse Rowe et al. case testimony]: Department of the Interior, Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Nowata, I. T., June 29th, 1901
FromThePage Description: Jesse Rowe, an African American Missionary Baptist minister from Delaware, Indian Territory, testifies on behalf of himself and his four grandchildren (Adamiah Seals, Alverta Seals, and Pearle Seals, and Clifford Seals) for enrollment as Cherokee Freedmen. He testifies that their mother (Lizzie Seals, his daughter) was born in Texas and is deceased. Jesse testifies that he was formerly enslaved by a Cherokee Indian called "Dick or Dave Rowe" from Spring Creek in the Canadian District. He claims that George Starr, his later enslaver, took him from the Flint District to Texas before the Civil War. Jesse returned to the Cherokee Nation (Fort Gibson and the Sequoyah District) several times after the war but continued to live off and on in Texas until 1890, when he returned to reside permanently in the Cherokee Nation. It is decided to place the applications of Jesse and his grandchildren on a 'doubtful card' for further consideration.

FromThePage Title: [Martha Albert et al. case testimonies]: Supplemental Testimony F.-D.#42: Department of the Interior, Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Vinita, I. T., May 21, 1901 [2 copies]
FromThePage Description: Testimony of Ruth Hunt, a Cherokee Freedman from Vinita on behalf of Martha Albert and her children for membership in the Cherokee Nation. Ruth testifies that she spent the Civil War in Fort Smith, Arkansas, and that Martha's husband worked for her family in 1867 after she returned to the Cherokee Nation. Also includes the testimonies of Emma Finley, the sister of Ruth Hunt, from Tahlequah Territory, and Harry Still, a Cherokee Freedman and former enslaved person. According to his testimony, Harry Still had been previously enslaved by George Whitmire, the brother of Johnson Whitmire, Martha Albert's former enslaver.

FromThePage Title: [Caroline Starr et al. case]: Letter from E.A. Hitchcock, the Secretary of the Interior, to the Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Muskogee, Indian Territory, June 24, 1905 [2 copies]
FromThePage Description: E.A. Hitchcock, Secretary of the Department of the Interior, informs the Commission that it has declined to grant a motion to re-open Caroline Starr's previously denied application for the enrollment of herself and her child, Johnnie Wesley McClure, as Cherokee Freedmen. The motion, filed by the applicant's lawyers, Neal and London of Fort Smith, Arkansas, included affidavits from three individuals. They each claim that Starr had returned to the Cherokee Nation after the Civil War at an earlier date than the one given in a testimony by E.W. Buffington, a relative of Caroline Starr. The Department decided that these statements lacked sufficient detail and were too general to justify a rehearing of this case.

FromThePage Title: [Robert Barnes and Martha Albert et al. testimonies]: Department of the Interior, Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Fort Gibson, I. T., April 18, 1901
FromThePage Description: Testimony of Robert Barnes, a formerly enslaved person living in the Sequoyah District in Oklahoma, on his own behalf, for enrollment as a Cherokee Freedman. Also includes the testimony of his uncle, Colly Albert from the Illinois District, Oklahoma on his behalf, as well as the testimony of his aunt, Martha Albert from Tahlequah District, Oklahoma, on behalf of herself and her two children. According to his testimony, Robert Barnes is the son of Sam and Jennie Barnes. Jennie, the sister of Martha Albert, was a formerly enslaved person who had been enslaved by Johnson Whitmire. Martha testifies that she and Jennie spent the Civil War in "Red River in the Choctaw Nation" but did not cross it to enter Texas. She returned to the Cherokee Nation after the war and testifies that her family (including Jennie and Colly) lived on the property of "Cale Starr" (also referred to as "Caleb Starr") in Sequoyah District where Robert Barnes and her oldest children were born.

FromThePage Title: [Phyllis Whitmire case]: Letter from Thos Ryan, Acting Secretary of the Department of the Interior to the Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Muskogee, Indian Territory, May 23, 1904
FromThePage Description: Thos. Ryan, the Acting Secretary of the Interior, informs the Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes about the Department's response to a recommendation from the Acting Commissioner of Indian Affairs (A.C. Tonner) to return the case of Phyllis Whitmire to the Commission for further review. This recommendation was based on the Acting Commissioner's belief that the testimonies in this case were unreliable with regard to whether Phyllis had returned to the Cherokee Nation from Kansas after the Civil War within the timeframe specified in the treaty of 1866. The Department of the Interior has decided that since the burden of proof had been upon the applicant, who had submitted unreliable testimony, the case does not need to be reopened. The Commission's decision to deny her application for Cherokee Freedmen enrollment, under provisions in the Curtis Act (passed by Congress on June 28, 1898). was approved by the Department of the Interior.

FromThePage Title: [Hartwell H. Houston et al. case testimonies]: Department of the Interior, Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Ft. Gibson, I.T., April 30, 1901
FromThePage Description: Testimony of Hartwell H. Houston, a "born free" African American who was never enslaved, for the enrollment of himself and his wife, Narcissus (also referred to in other documents as "Narcissa") as Cherokee Freedmen. After serving as a soldier in the Civil War, Hartwell returned to the Cherokee Nation in 1866, where he owns a farm. He testifies that he has also lived in the Choctaw Nation (South McAlester) and Van Buren, and has been living in Fort Smith since May of 1900. George W. Vann, his cousin, and Horace S. Norman, an acquaintance, also testify on his behalf. At the conclusion of the testimony, it is noted that Hartwell does not appear in any of the tribal rolls of the Cherokee Nation. The decision was made to place Hartwell's case on a "doubtful card" for further consideration, and to reject the application of his wife, a formerly enslaved person.

FromThePage Title: [Parmelia Rowe at al. case testimonies]: Department of the Interior, Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Chelsea, I. T., June 11, 1901
FromThePage Description: Parmelia Rowe, a former enslaved African American, testifies on behalf of herself and her three children (Nancy, Salina, Colis) to be enrolled as Cherokee Freemen. The testimonies of Peter Williams, Jack Jones (Parmelia's half-brother), Charles Mayfield, and Columbus McNair are also included. Parmelia testifies that she was formerly enslaved by Sallie Mayfield, a Cherokee citizen from Flint District, who took her to Texas as a child before the Civil War, where her children were born. Parmelia testifies that she returned to the Cherokee Nation in 1866 but did not permanently reside there with her children until 12 or 13 years before the time of this hearing. Peter William sand Charles Mayfield, who claims that his former enslaver, Walker Mayfield, was Sallie Mayfield's brother, testify that they saw Parmelia in Fort Gibson about a year after the Civil War. It is concluded that the testimonies failed to prove that Parmelia had returned within the timeframe specified in the "treaty of 1866." Her case is listed upon a "doubtful card" future consideration by the Commission.

FromThePage Description: Testimony of Albert Johnson, Andy Crossland, Rose Rogers on behalf of Martha Albert, a formerly enslaved person, and her children for membership in the Cherokee Nation. FromThePage Title: [Ed Williams case]: Letter from A. C. Tonner, Acting Commissioner of Indian Affairs, to the Secretary of the Interior, Washington, May 23, 1904
FromThePage Description: Letter from A. C. Tonner, the Acting Commissioner of Indian Affairs to the Secretary of the Interior, transmitting a report from the Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, with their recommendation to deny enrollment as a Cherokee Freedman to Ed Williams. Tonner states that there does not appear to be any evidence to prove that his parents were taken out of the Cherokee Nation during the Civil War or that they had returned afterwards. Tonner recommends that the Department of Interior reopen the case to allow further testimony.

FromThePage Title: In the matter of the application of Parmelia Rowe, C. F. D. 681: Supplemental testimony, Department of the Interior, Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Vinita, I. T., October 15th, 1901
FromThePage Description: James M. Bell and Zeek Starr provide supplemental testimony on behalf of the applicants in the Parmelia Rowe et al. case for enrollment as Cherokee Freedmen. James M. Bell of Delaware District testifies that he knew "Aunt" Sallie Mayfield, the enslaver of Parmelia Rowe, in the Cherokee Nation before she moved to Texas in 1847, and that his father had moved to Rusk County, Texas, during the same year. He testifies that he did not know Parmelia Rowe or the names of any of the people who were enslaved by Sallie Mayfield. He testifies knowing Jess Rowe, who was formerly enslaved by George Starr and also came to Texas in 1847. Bell claims that Sallie Mayfield, Jess Rowe, and his father were all "Cherokee by blood" and have continuously resided in Texas. Zeek Starr, the son of George Starr, testifies that he was born in Texas in 1849, after his family had moved there, and that Jess, one of their enslaved persons, lived with them there during the Civil War. He also testifies that he knew "Aunt" Sallie Mayfield in Texas and that his father was re-admitted as a Cherokee citizen after returning to the Cherokee Nation after the war.

Albert Johnson, from Sequoyah District, testifies that he was a former neighbor of Martha Albert. Andy Crossland, a former enslaved person and Confederate soldier from the Illinois District, testifies that he lived in Sequoyah District before the Civil War. He recalls first meeting Martha at Cale Starr's plantation near Fort Smith, Arkansas. Rose Rogers, a formerly enslaved person from Saline District, testifies that she knew Martha when they were children in Goingsnake District before the Civil War, and that Martha and her family had been enslaved by Johnson Whitmire. She also testifies spending the Civil War in the Choctaw Nation.

FromThePage Title: Decision: in the matter of the application for the enrollment of Fannie Vann as a Cherokee Freedman
FromThePage Description: The official decision of the Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes to deny the application of Fannie Vann, a formerly enslaved African American, for citizenship in the Cherokee Nation. Based on evidence that was presented during a hearing in Fort Gibson, Indian Territory, it is found that she had been enslaved by a Cherokee citizen, was taken out of the Cherokee Nation during the Civil War, and did not return until 1888. Her name was also not found in the 1880 authenticated Cherokee tribal roll. Her case was denied based on provisions in the Curtis Act, passed by Congress on June 28, 1898.

FromThePage Title: [Houston West case testimonies]: Department of the Interior, Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Ft. Gibson, September 4, 1901 [2 copies]
FromThePage Description: W.T. Harnage, Ezekiel Harnage, and D.M. Falkner testify on behalf of Houston West, a formerly enslaved African American, for enrollment as a Cherokee Freedman. W.T. Harnage, a "Cherokee citizen by blood" testifies that he is the nephew of Houston West's former enslaver, Walker Mayfield, and that Walker returned from Texas to the Sequoyah District in the Cherokee Nation 1867. Ezekiel Harnage, the cousin of W.T. Harnage, testifies that both he and W.T. Harnage were in Texas during the Civil War, and that he knew Houston West. D.M. Falkner, another "Cherokee by blood" testifies that he married Rachel L. Adair, who claimed to be the niece of Walker Mayfield.

FromThePage Description: Testimony of Martha Albert, a former enslaved African American living in the Tahlequah District, Oklahoma, for enrollment as a Cherokee Freedman. Brown testifies that he was formerly enslaved by John Brown and spent the Civil War in the Choctaw Nation, returning to the Cherokee Nation in 1865 and settling in the Canadian District. FromThePage Title: [Lula Knalls et al. case testimonies]: Department of the Interior, Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Fort Gibson, I. T., April 18, 1901
FromThePage Description: Testimony of Lula Knalls on behalf of herself and her three children for enrollment as Cherokee Freedmen. Martha Albert, her aunt, also serves as a witness during this hearing. Lula is the daughter of "Jenny Barnes" and the half-sister of Robert Barnes. Although Lula claims to have lived in the Cherokee Nation (on "Lee's Creek" and in the Sequoyah District) during her entire life, she cannot be identified on the census rolls of 1880 or 1896, or on the Kerns-Clifton roll. The decision is made to list Lula, as well as her daughter Sarah French and her son, Fred E. Knalls, on a "doubtful card" for further consideration. Meanwhile, her oldest son, Frank Gardner, who was twenty-two years old at the time, would be required to apply separately on his own behalf.

FromThePage Description: In this letter, A.C. Tonner, the Acting Commissioner of the Office of Indian Affairs presents a report from the Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes to the U.S. Secretary of the Interior, dated March 15, 1904. He describes the reasons behind the Commission's decision to reject the Cherokee Freedmen application for Jesse Hicks and his son (William Hicks"). It describes how Hicks, who was formerly enslaved by a Cherokee citizen, left the Cherokee Nation during the Civil War, returning to it in 1867, only to relocate to Kansas for the next twenty ears. In the meantime, his son, born in 1887, is declared to have "no right as a Cherokee Freedman except as derived from his father." The letter ends with a recommendation of this decision.

FromThePage Title: [Ed Williams case]: Letter from Thos Ryan, Acting Secretary of the Interior to the Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Muskogee, Indian Territory, May 27, 1904
FromThePage Description: Thos Ryan, the Acting Secretary of the Interior, informs the Commission of his response to a recommendation from the Office of Indian Affairs to reopen the case of Ed Williams, the son of formerly enslaved African Americans. The Indian Office had stated that the evidence presented had been insufficient to prove whether Ed Williams' parents, Pomp Williams and Charity Quinton, were taken out of the Cherokee Nation during the Civil War or returned to it, other than the fact that Ed Williams was born in 1866 in the Cherokee Nation. In this letter, Ryan states that the Department of the Interior does not agree with the recommendation to reopen the case, and argues that the burden of proof is upon the applicant who did not supply reliable testimony in this case. Due to this reasoning, the Department of the Interior has decided to approve the Commission's original decision to deny his case for enrollment as a Cherokee Freedman.

He is questioned about Josephine, his then deceased wife and the mother of his daughter. He and his mother also testify about the places that he had resided, including Texas, where he lived off and on for many years. FromThePage Title: [Katie Vann et al. case testimony]: Department of the Interior, Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Muskogee, Indian Territory, August 30, 1902
FromThePage Description: Testimony of Katie Vann, the daughter of formerly enslaved African Americans who was born after the Civil War, for the enrollment of herself and children (Lou, Robert, Granville, Areminta, Lydia, Florence, Dollie, George, and Ethel Vann) as Cherokee Freedmen. Katie testifies that she lives in Chelsea in Cooweescoowee District, and that she was born in Big Creek, Cherokee Nation. After her mother died, she moved to Kansas where her two oldest children were born. She testifies that she returned to the Cherokee Nation, where most of her children were born, but that Lydia had been born in Kansas. It is concluded that the Commission is "without authority to receive, consider of make any record of this application" due to an injunction granted by "Judge Gill of the United States Court, Northern District, Indian Territory," and that this case will be denied.

FromThePage Title: Decision: in the matter of the applications for the enrollment of Katie Vann, et al., as Cherokee Freedmen
FromThePage Description: The official decision of the Commissioner to the Five Civilized Tribes to deny the applications in the consolidated case of Katie Vann et al. The application of Katie Vann, the daughter of formerly enslaved African Americans, for Cherokee Freedmen enrollment for herself and nine of her children (Lou, Robert, Granville, Areminta, Lydia, Florence, Dollie, George, and Ethel Vann) had previously been denied, as it was not proven that Katie's parents had complied with provisions in the "treaty of 1866" to return to the Cherokee Nation within six months after the end of the Civil War. Ray and Tessey Vann, also children of Katie Vann, later applied in 1906. None of the applicants could be identified on the Cherokee authenticated tribal roll of 1880 or on any other roll. It is decided that this case will be denied according to provisions in the "Act of Congress approved April 26, 1906 (34 Stat. 137)," also known as: "An act to provide for the final disposition of the affairs of the Five Civilized Tribes in the Indian Territory, and for other purposes."

FromThePage Title: [Martha Albert case testimonies]: Department of the Interior, Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Fort Gibson, I. T., April 18, 1901 [Supplemental Testimony A]
FromThePage Description: Testimony of Martha Albert, a former enslaved African American living in the Tahlequah District, Oklahoma, for enrollment as a Cherokee Freedman. Also includes the testimony of Henry Brown, from the Illinois District, on her behalf. Brown testifies that he was formerly enslaved by John Brown and spent the Civil War in the Choctaw Nation, returning to the Cherokee Nation in 1865 and settling in the Canadian District. He claims to have seen Martha with other individuals who were formerly enslaved by the Whitmire family at a church after the war, while staying in Fort Smith to attend the trial of Green Lowry that was presided over by a "Judge Parker."

FromThePage Title: [Robert Barnes and Martha Albert et al. testimonies]: Department of the Interior, Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Fort Gibson, I. T., April 18, 1901
FromThePage Description: Testimony of Robert Barnes, a formerly enslaved person living in the Sequoyah District in Oklahoma, on his own behalf, for enrollment as a Cherokee Freedman. Also includes the testimony of his uncle, Colly Albert from the Illinois District, Oklahoma on his behalf, as well as the testimony of his aunt, Martha Albert from Tahlequah District, Oklahoma, on behalf of herself and her two children. According to his testimony, Robert Barnes is the son of Sam and Jennie Barnes. Jennie, the sister of Martha Albert, was a formerly enslaved person who had been enslaved by Johnson Whitmire. Martha testifies that she and Jennie spent the Civil War in "Red River in the Choctaw Nation" but did not cross it to enter Texas. She returned to the Cherokee Nation after the war and testifies that her family (including Jennie and Colly) lived on the property of "Cale Starr" (also referred to as "Caleb Starr") in Sequoyah District where Robert Barnes and her oldest children were born.

FromThePage Title: Decision : in the matter of the application for the enrollment of John May and his minor children, Sophia, Ettie, Minnie, Elmer, Idella and Nellie May, as Cherokee Freedmen

FromThePage Title: [Sallie Mayfield et al. case testimonies]: Department of the Interior, Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Fort Gibson, I. T., April 12, 1901
FromThePage Description: Testimony of Sallie Mayfield, a formerly enslaved African American, on behalf of herself and her three sons (including Thomas Mayfield, her oldest) for enrollment as Cherokee Freedmen. Sallie testifies that she was taken to Texas by her enslaver, a Cherokee citizen, and had "run away from there" to return to the Cherokee Nation around 1866, where she has lived ever since. George Amos Mayfield testifies that he knew Sallie Mayfield before the Civil War when she was enslaved by a "Miss Sallie Mayfield" when he lived in Flint District. He testifies that he first saw her at "Walk Mayfield's place" after returning to the Cherokee Nation from Texas. He claimed that she lived in the Canadian District and spent some time in Muskogee before moving to the Illinois District. G. W. Vann (also identified as "George Vann" by Sallie) also testifies that she had gone to Texas during the Civil War. Commissioner Needles concludes that Sallie should be placed on a "doubtful card" for further consideration, and that her name has not been found on the "authenticated roll of 1880" or the tribal roll of 1896.

FromThePage Title: Decision: in the matter of the application of Dollie Umphuris for enrollment as a Cherokee Freedman
FromThePage Description: The official decision of the Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes to deny the application of Dollie Umphuris for citizenship in the Cherokee Nation. Based on evidence presented during proceedings that took place at Fort Gibson, Indian Territory, it is determined that she had been enslaved by John Harnage. A Cherokee citizen prior to 1856, had taken her to Texas during that year, and was re-admitted to citizenship in the Cherokee Nation after he returned in 1881. Dollie Umphuris was not identified in the 1880 authenticated Cherokee tribal roll. It is concluded by the Commission that Dollie had not been enslaved by a Cherokee citizen at the beginning of the war, and that her case should be denied according to provisions in the Curtis Act, passed by Congress on June 28, 1898.

FromThePage Title: [Robert Barnes and Martha Albert et al. testimonies]: Department of the Interior, Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Fort Gibson, I. T., April 18, 1901
FromThePage Description: Testimony of Robert Barnes, a formerly enslaved person living in the Sequoyah District in Oklahoma, on his own behalf, for enrollment as a Cherokee Freedman. Also includes the testimony of his uncle, Colly Albert from the Illinois District, Oklahoma on his behalf, as well as the testimony of his aunt, Martha Albert from Tahlequah District, Oklahoma, on behalf of herself and her two children. According to his testimony, Robert Barnes is the son of Sam and Jennie Barnes. Jennie, the sister of Martha Albert, was a formerly enslaved person who had been enslaved by Johnson Whitmire. Martha testifies that she and Jennie spent the Civil War in "Red River in the Choctaw Nation" but did not cross it to enter Texas. She returned to the Cherokee Nation after the war and testifies that her family (including Jennie and Colly) lived on the property of "Cale Starr" (also referred to as "Caleb Starr") in Sequoyah District where Robert Barnes and her oldest children were born.

FromThePage Title: [Susan Harlin et al. case testimonies]: Department of the Interior, Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Ft. Gibson, I. T., April 23, 1901
FromThePage Description: Testimonies on behalf of Susan Harlin, a formerly enslaved person from Tahlequah District, for membership in the Cherokee Nation. Susan begins by testifying on her own behalf and her two minor children (Elizabeth Blue and Calvin Blue). She testifies that she was enslaved by John Brewer, the father of Bill Brewer, and that her first husband was a Chickasaw Freedman named Tim Blue. She stayed in the Chickasaw Nation during the Civil War, returning to the Cherokee Nation approximately 12 years prior to her testimony. Jenetta Harlin testifies that she has known Susan during her entire life in the Chickasaw Nation and that Susan had been married at the time to Bass Harlin, a Cherokee Freedman. Commissioner Breckinridge concludes the testimony by stating that Susan will be enrolled as a Cherokee Freedman by intermarriage on a "doubtful card," but rejects the enrollment of Elizabeth and Calvin Blue, who are not identified in any registry.

FromThePage Title: Decision: in the matter of the application of Caroline Starr for the enrollment of herself and her minor child,  John W. McClure, as Cherokee Freedmen
FromThePage Description: The official decision of the Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes to deny the application of Caroline Starr and her son, John W. McClure. It was decided that this case should be denied under provisions of the Curtis Act of June 28, 2898.

Formerly enslaved by Johnson Whitmire of Goingsnake District, she lived in the "Cale Starr place" near Lee's Creek during the Civil War, returning to "Cherokee Territory" with Ellis Harlin in 1866. Also includes testimonies from John Melton and Mandy Benton, both Cherokee Freedmen, who met her after the war. It is determined that Martha Albert appears in the "Kerns-Clifton" roll, but not in the 1880 tribal roll or the Census roll of 1896. Judgment is suspended and their names placed on a "doubtful card" for further consideration.

FromThePage Title: [A testimony] in the matter of the application for the enrollment of Martha Albert et al. as Cherokee Freedmen [May 11, 1905]
FromThePage Description: Testimony of Aaron Whitmire, a Cherokee Freedman, on behalf of Martha Albert, a formerly enslaved person, and her children, for membership in the Cherokee Nation. Prior to the Civil War, Aaron had been enslaved by George Whitmire, the brother of Martha's owner, Johnson Whitmire, in Goingsnake District, He testifies as to whether Martha Albert and her mother Nancy had been sold to Dillingham, a man from Arkansas, who allegedly moved them to Texas. He also testifies as to whether another enslaved person with the name "Martha" had been living on the Whitmire farm at the time. Upon this additional testimony the Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes made a decision to file a motion for continuance.

FromThePage Title: [Betsy Reed et al. case testimonies]: Department of the Interior, Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Vinita, I. T., October 26th, 1901
FromThePage Description: Testimony of Betsy Reed a former enslaved African American, for the enrollment of herself and her five grandchildren (Silas Harris, Mamie Harris, Hannah Brown, Myrtle Brown, Mima Harris) as Cherokee Freedmen. The testimonies of Sam Webber, Harry Still, John H. Coody and Henry Armstrong are also included. Betsy testifies that she was formerly enslaved by "Aleck McPherson," a Cherokee citizen, who lived on "Dog Creek" in the Cherokee Nation. She moved to Mound City, Kansas during the Civil War. She testifies that she has lived off and on in Mound City since the war ended, and has returned to the Cherokee Nation several times. Sam Webber and Harry Still testify that they saw her near Coody's Bluff in the Cherokee Nation in 1866. and that she returned to the Cherokee Nation again during the Wallace roll. Meanwhile, Betsy could not be identified in any of the Cherokee tribal rolls except for the Kern-Clifton roll. It is decided that Betsy and her grandchildren are to be placed on a "doubtful card" for further consideration by the Commission.

FromThePage Title: [Ruthie Wright et al. case]: Letter from Thos Ryan, First Assistant Secretary of the Interior to the Commissioner to the Five Civilized Tribes, Muskogee, Indian Territory, January 26, 1906 [5 copies]
FromThePage Description: In a letter to the Commissioner to the Five Civilized Tribes, Thomas Ryan, the First Assistant Secretary to the Interior, explains the Department's decision to deny a motion to reopen the case of Ruthie Wright et al. for enrollment as Cherokee Freedmen. The Department had previously approved the Commissioner's decision to deny their application, concurring with the conclusion that the applicants were not entitled to the benefits of the treaty of 1866. The motion to reopen this case was denied after the Department found evidence that contradicted Ruthie Wright's claim to have been a "free" person living in the Nation at the start of the Civil War. Instead, she was found to have escaped from Mary Ann Bright, her enslaver at the time, from Fort Smith, Arkansas to the Cherokee Nation, and had lived there as a free person ever since.

FromThePage Title: Decision: in the matter of the application of Robert Mayfield for enrollment as a Cherokee Freedman
FromThePage Description: The official decision of the Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes to deny the application of Robert Mayfield for enrollment as a Cherokee Freedmen. Based on evidence presented at four separate hearings in 1901, it was concluded that Robert had been taken to Texas by his former enslaver, a Cherokee citizen, in 1847, and had not returned to the Cherokee Nation until January 1868. His name was also not found in the "1880 authenticated Cherokee Roll." It was decided to deny this case, according to provisions in the Curtis Act, passed by Congress on June 28, 1898.

FromThePage Title: [Katie Thornton et al. case testimonies]: Department of the Interior, Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Chelsea, I. T., June 7, 1901
FromThePage Description: Testimonies given on behalf of Katie Thornton, a former enslaved African American, for the enrollment of herself and her two minor children (Millie and Emma) as Cherokee Freedmen. Katie Thornton testifies that she had been enslaved by John Thornton, a Cherokee citizen, and had been taken from Goingsnake District to Fort Scott, Kansas, during the Civil War. She returned in 1866, and testifies that she has lived in the Nation with her children ever since. Her husband Henry, a Cherokee Freedmen, had served in the army until he was discharged after becoming disabled by an injury, and the family moved to Garnett, Kansas. Harry Stills Frank Ross, and Lewis Whitmire, a self-described Cherokee citizen, testify that they had seen her living "on Lightning Creek" in 1866, and that she now lives near "Big Creek" in the Cherokee Nation. They also answer questions about her children, including Maggie Curls, her oldest. Also includes are testimonies of Jack Landrum, on his own behalf, and that of George Bruckner, in response to an objection from attorney W.W. Hastings to Jack Landrum as a witness. It is found that Katie cannot be identified in 1880 authenticated and 1896 census rolls, but the names of herself and her two children are listed in the Kern-Clifton roll as living in the Cooweescoowee District. Their case will be listed on a "doubtful card" for further consideration.

FromThePage Title: [Dollie Umphuris case]: Letter from A. C. Tonner, Acting Secretary of the Office of Indian Affairs to the Secretary of the Interior, Washington, June 1, 1904
FromThePage Description: A.C. Tonner, the Acting Secretary of Indian Affairs, informs the Secretary of the Interior of the decision by the Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes to deny Dollie Umphuris' application for enrollment as a Cherokee Freedman. The reasoning behind this decision is explained, including how her enslaver, John Harnage, had been a Cherokee citizen prior to 1856, when he took Dollie Umphuris with him to Texas. However, John Harnage did not return to the Cherokee Nation until 1881 and was readmitted as a citizen to the Nation. Dollie Umphuris was also not identified in the 1880 authenticated Cherokee tribal roll. Based on this evidence, the Commission decided that Dollie was not enslaved by a Cherokee citizen when the Civil War started. The Acting Commissioner of Indian Affairs recommends that the Commission's decision be approved.

FromThePage Title: Decision: in the matter of the application of Ruthie Wright for the enrollment of herself and minor children, Henry, Nora, Minnie and Anna Wright, as Cherokee Freedmen
FromThePage Description: The official decision of the Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes to deny the application of Ruthie Wright and her minor children (Henry, Nora, Minnie and Anna) for enrollment as Cherokee Freedmen. The evidence cited includes the finding that Ruthie was formerly enslaved by Mary Bright, in Arkansas, and that neither she nor her children had been enslaved by Cherokee citizens or free African Americans in the Cherokee Nation. None of their names were found on the 1880 Cherokee tribal roll, and the father of her children claimed to be a Choctaw Freedmen. It was concluded that Ruthie and her children were not entitled to citizenship in the Cherokee Nation, under provisions specified within the Curtis Act, approved by Congress on June 28, 1898.

FromThePage Title: [Peggy A. Rowe et al. case testimonies]: Department of the Interior, Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Chelsea, I. T., June 10, 1901 [3 copies]
FromThePage Description: Testimony of "Peggie Archer Rowe" and Katie Vann, for the enrollment of Peggie, her four children (Dinah, Katie, Annie, Ruthie) and three grandchildren (Clarence Simmons, Rogers Wheat, and Agnes Porter) as Cherokee Freedmen. Rowe testifies that she was born in Saline District in the Cherokee Nation, and that she and her sister, "Clarinda Vann," were sent by Polly Archer, their Cherokee enslaver, to Texas prior to the Civil War. Peggie testifies that although she returned to the Cherokee Nation in 1866, she has resided in the Muscogee (Creek) Nation with her husband, a Seminole Nation member named "George Rowe," ever since. Katie Vann testifies that she had seen Peggie in 1866 during a trip to Fort Gibson in the Cherokee Nation. Finally, Peggie is questioned about her oldest child "Cullie," who was born in the "Concharta District" [possibly "Concharty"?) in the Creek Nation. It is decided that Peggie and her family should be put on a "doubtful card" for further consideration, and that "satisfactory proof" is needed of the birth of her children and grandchildren, as they do not appear on any Cherokee tribal rolls.

FromThePage Title: [Katie Thornton et al. case]: [Incomplete copy of testimonies], Department of the Interior, Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Vinita, I. T., October 26, 1901
FromThePage Description: The last two pages of a hearing containing testimony by William Ray and Harry Still (who was recalled as a witness) for the Cherokee Nation in Katie Thornton's case (C.F.D. 578) for the enrollment of herself and her two minor children as Cherokee Freedmen. William Ray testifies that he knew Katie and her husband Henry Thornton when they had lived in Garnett, Kansas, but could not remember their children. He claims that Katie and Henry left for the Cherokee Nation with his sister and his brother-in-law, John Tyler, in 1871. Harry Still testifies about the name of Katie's husband, his occupation, and that confirms that Henry had been disabled.

FromThePage Title: [George Alberty case testimonies]: Department of the Interior, Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Muskogee, Indian Territory, October 21, 1902
FromThePage Description: Testimony of George Alberty, the son of formerly enslaved African Americans, for membership in the Cherokee Nation. He testifies that he was born in Texas, and came to the Cherokee Nation in 1883. He states that he now lives in the Illinois District in Oklahoma, and that his parents, William and Lilah Alberty, were born in the Cherokee Nation and are also Freedmen. The Commission denied his application, as it could not find his name on any of the tribal rolls held by the Commission.

FromThePage Title: [Martha et al. case testimonies]: Department of the Interior, Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Muskogee, Indian Territory, April 27, 1905
FromThePage Description: Testimonies on behalf of Martha Albert, a formerly enslaved person, for membership in the Cherokee Nation after her application was remanded by the Secretary of the Interior for further hearing. Testimonies include those of individuals who were acquainted with Johnson Whitmire, Martha's former enslaver, in Goingsnake District before the Civil War: A.J. ("Andy") Alberty, a Cherokee ("by blood"), Cale Wright from Tahlequah District, Jeff Catcher (a.k.a. "Jeff Tik-nee-sky"), a Cherokee citizen, and J.W. Alberty, who had previously testified on Martha's behalf. Also includes testimonies from Watt (a.k.a. "Walter") Whitmire, son of Johnson (a.k.a.. "Jonathan") Whitmire, and Charlotte Wright and Charles Whitmire, the children of Johnson's brother, George. A.J. Alberty testifies that there had been another enslaved person named "Martha" on the Whitmire farm prior to the Civil War, who had been sold to a man called Dillingham from Arkansas. He claims that Martha Albert and her family did not go to Texas, but had spent the Civil War in the Choctaw Nation in Red River. The rest of the witnesses discuss their recollections about whether Martha and her mother Nancy had been living on the Whitmire farm prior to the Civil War, and whether they had seen them living in the Choctaw Nation after the war began.

FromThePage Title: [Dollie Umphuris case]: Letter from "Dollie Humphrey" [Dollie  Umphuris]  to a "Mr. Hiscox" [most likely E. A. Hitchcock], Fort Gibson, Indian Territory, June 23, 1906 [4 copies]
FromThePage Description: Letter from "Dollie Humphrey" [Dollie Umphuris], which may have been partially written by her husband on her behalf. Addressed to "Mr. Hiscox" (probably E.A. Hitchcock, the Secretary of the Interior), the letter inquires why Dollie was not listed in one of the Cherokee tribal rolls (probably 1880, since her case had been denied on that basis). It claims that Dollie had returned to the Cherokee Nation in 1866 as a freed person, and that she had "met" the Wallace roll, as well as the Kerns-Clifton roll. The letter requests that her case for citizenship in the Cherokee Nation be re-opened in order for this evidence to be considered.

title: [Dollie Umphuris case]: Letter from "Dollie Humphrey" [Dollie  Umphuris]  to a "Mr. Hiscox" [most likely E. A. Hitchcock], Fort Gibson, Indian Territory, June 23, 1906 [4 copies]
abstract: Letter from "Dollie Humphrey" [Dollie Umphuris], which may have been partially written by her husband on her behalf. Addressed to "Mr. Hiscox" (probably E.A. Hitchcock, the Secretary of the Interior), the letter inquires why Dollie was not listed in one of the Cherokee tribal rolls (probably 1880, since her case had been denied on that basis). It claims that Dollie had returned to the Cherokee Nation in 1866 as a freed person, and that she had "met" the Wallace roll, as well as the Kerns-Clifton roll. The letter requests that her case for citizenship in the Cherokee Nation be re-opened in order for this evidence to be considered.

FromThePage Title: [Phyllis Whitmire case]: Letter from A. C. Tonner, Acting Commissioner of Indian Affairs to the Secretary of the Interior, Washington, February 6, 1904
FromThePage Description: A. C. Tonner, Acting Commissioner to the Office of Indian Affairs, informs the Secretary of the Interior that there is conflicting evidence about whether Phyllis Whitmire, a formerly enslaved African American, returned to the Cherokee Nation within the timeframe specified by the treaty of 1866 after the end of the Civil War. Her name is also not found on the authenticated Cherokee tribal roll of 1880, but appears in the Kerns-Clifton roll and Wallace rolls. The testimonial evidence that she did not return within six months after this treaty appear to be "largely guess-work" on the part of witnesses who testified. Tonner also questions placing the burden of proof on the applicant. He recommends that the case be returned to the Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes and that the Commission explain the reasoning behind their decision to deny her application.

FromThePage Title: [Hannah West case testimonies]: Department of the Interior, Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Fort Gibson, I. T., September 4, 1901 [4 copies]
FromThePage Description: Mark Bean, a "Cherokee by blood" and L. B. Bell testify on behalf of Hannah West, a formerly enslaved African American, for enrollment as a Cherokee Freedmen. Both Mark Bean and L.B. Bell testify that they knew Sallie Mayfield, a former Cherokee citizen from Flint District, who relocated to "Russ" [i.e., Rusk] County, Texas in 1847 and returned in 1868 or 1869. Bell testifies that she had moved to Texas due to disturbances "arising out of the treaty of 1835." Finally, both witnesses testify that Sallie was later re-admitted as a citizen of the Cherokee Nation, but that they did not know Hannah, or whether she had been among the persons enslaved by Sallie.

FromThePage Title: Supplemental proceedings in the matter of the application for the enrollment of  Charlotte Potts, et al., as Cherokee Freedmen [November 22, 1904]
FromThePage Description: Fannie Miller and Mary A. Walker testify before the Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes, Muskogee, Indian Territory in the Cherokee Freedmen enrollment case of Charlotte Potts et al. Fannie Miller testifies that Charlotte was formerly enslaved by Betsy Scott, and that she had become acquainted with Charlotte and her mother, Myra, during the Civil War, when they had relocated to Fort Gibson. She testifies that Charlotte and her mother had moved to Webbers Falls later during the war. Mary A. Walker, the daughter of Sterling Scott (Betsy Scott's husband) is questioned about the persons enslaved by her father, and that she did not know Charlotte Potts and denies that he had ever enslaved Myra.

FromThePage Description: "Cullie Rowe" testifies on his own behalf for enrollment as a Cherokee citizen. He claims that he lives in the Creek Nation near Choska and that his district is Cooweescoowee. He testifies that his father is George Rowe, a member of the Seminole Nation, and that his mother is "Beckey Rowe," a Cherokee Freedman, who was previously enslaved by "Polly Archie" (also referred to in other documents as "Polly Archer"). His enrollment was refused due to his name not being found on the authenticated Cherokee tribal roll of 1880.

FromThePage Title: Decision: in the matter of the application for the  enrollment of Sallie Mayfield et al., as Cherokee Freedmen, consolidating the applications of Sallie Mayfield (Cherokee Freedmen D-91), Thomas Mayfield et al. (Cherokee Freedmen D-124), Emberry Mayfield,
FromThePage Description: The official decision of the Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes to deny the applications of Sallie Mayfield, her son Thomas Mayfield and his nine children, and Emberry Mayfield and his family, for enrollment as Cherokee Freedmen. The Commission cites testimonial evidence that Sallie and Thomas were formerly enslaved by a Cherokee citizen prior to the Civil War, and were taken by their enslaver to Texas at its commencement. They did not return to the Cherokee Nation within the required timeframe, as decreed from the 1896 case of "Moses Whitmire, trustee, etc. vs. the Cherokee Nation et al." None of the applicants were identified on the "authenticated" 1880 Cherokee tribal roll. It was decided to deny this case, according to provisions in the Curtis Act, passed by Congress in June 28, 1898.

FromThePage Title: [A testimony] in the matter of the application for the enrollment of Martha Albert et al. as Cherokee Freedmen [May 11, 1905]
FromThePage Description: Testimony of Aaron Whitmire, a Cherokee Freedman, on behalf of Martha Albert, a formerly enslaved person, and her children for membership in the Cherokee Nation. Prior to the Civil War, Aaron had been enslaved by George Whitmire, the brother of Martha's owner, Johnson Whitmire, in Goingsnake District, He testifies as to whether Martha Albert and her mother Nancy had been sold to Dillingham, a man from Arkansas, who allegedly moved them to Texas. He also testifies as to whether another enslaved person with the name "Martha" had been living on the Whitmire farm at the time. Upon this additional testimony the Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes made a decision to file a motion for continuance.

FromThePage Description: A.C. Tonner, the Acting Indian Commissioner, informs the Secretary of the Interior that he recommends the Commission to the Five Civilized Tribes' decision to reject Hartwell H. Houston's application for the enrollment of himself and his wife, Narcissa Houston, as Cherokee Freedmen.
